definitions.definition: using the hand or number of hands mentioned

examples.text: a one-handed catch
left-handed scissors *(= intended to be held in your left hand)*

definitions.definition: help in doing something

examples.text: The neighbours are always willing to **lend a hand**.
Let me **give you a hand** with those bags *(= help you to carry them)*.
Do you **need a hand** with those invoices?

definitions.definition: the part or role that somebody/something plays in a particular situation; somebody’s influence in a situation

examples.text: Early reports suggest the hand of rebel forces in the bombings.
Several of his colleagues **had a hand in** his downfall.
This appointment was an attempt to **strengthen her hand** in policy discussions.

definitions.definition: a part of a clock or watch that points to the numbers
a person who does physical work on a farm or in a factory

examples.text: The farmer would bring in hired hands to help harvest the crop.

definitions.definition: a sailor on a ship

examples.text: All hands on deck!

definitions.definition: by a person rather than a machine

examples.text: hand-painted pottery
hand-knitted
This item should be hand-washed.
Mail for hand delivery is put in a separate tray.

definitions.definition: a set of playing cards given to one player in a game

examples.text: to be dealt a **good/bad hand**
She felt that life had dealt her a bad hand.

definitions.definition: one stage of a game of cards

examples.text: I'll have to leave after this hand.
Who dealt the last hand?

definitions.definition: a particular style of writing
a unit for measuring the height of a horse, equal to 4 inches or 10.16 centimetres
everyone helps or must help, especially in a difficult situation

examples.text: There are 30 people coming to dinner tonight, so it's all hands on deck.

definitions.definition: close to you in time or distance

examples.text: Help was at hand.
The property is ideally located with all local amenities close at hand.

definitions.definition: if you experience something at the hands of somebody, they are the cause of it

examples.text: They suffered years of repression at the hands of the old regime.

definitions.definition: to show skill at making or doing things with your hands
to tie somebody’s hands and feet together so that they cannot move or escape
to prevent somebody from doing what they want by creating rules, limits, etc.
it is better to keep something that you already have than to risk losing it by trying to get much more
to harm somebody who has helped you or supported you
by a person rather than a machine

examples.text: The fabric was painted by hand.
Delicate clothes should be washed by hand.
We can apply the power of computational tools in solving mathematical problems that cannot be solved by hand.

definitions.definition: if a letter is delivered by hand, it is delivered by the person who wrote it, or somebody who is sent by them, rather than by post
if you pay for goods and services cash in hand, you pay in cash, especially so that the person being paid can avoid paying tax on the amount

examples.text: a cash-in-hand payment of £20

definitions.definition: to pass to a different owner

examples.text: The house has changed hands several times.

definitions.definition: near; in a place where somebody/something can be reached easily

examples.text: There are good cafes and a restaurant close at hand.

definitions.definition: an influence that controls or limits something

examples.text: We need to free business from the dead hand of bureaucracy.

definitions.definition: people who do not have enough to do often start to do wrong

examples.text: She blamed the crimes on the local jobless teenagers. ‘The devil makes work for idle hands,’ she would say.

definitions.definition: to trust somebody and be willing to do what they say

examples.text: She'll have them eating out of her hand in no time.

definitions.definition: to become controlled by somebody

examples.text: The town fell into enemy hands.
We don't want this document **falling into the wrong hands**.
After the war, the hotel fell into the hands of an American consortium.

definitions.definition: strong control or discipline

examples.text: Some children need a firm hand to make them behave.

definitions.definition: by experiencing, seeing, etc. something yourself rather than being told about it by somebody else

examples.text: The President visited the area to see the devastation at first hand.

definitions.definition: to bring or hold your hands together

examples.text: She kept her hands folded in her lap.

definitions.definition: to make somebody do something that they do not want to do or make them do it sooner than they had intended

examples.text: They decided to strike to force the management’s hand.

definitions.definition: to get an advantage over somebody so that you are in control of a particular situation
to do physical work

examples.text: He's not frightened of getting his hands dirty.

definitions.definition: to get, have, etc. the opportunity to do what you want to do and to make your own decisions

examples.text: I was given a free hand in designing the syllabus.

definitions.definition: to show your approval of somebody by clapping your hands; to be applauded in this way

examples.text: Ladies and gentlemen, let’s give a big hand to our special guests tonight.

definitions.definition: to help somebody
to ask somebody for something, especially money, in a very polite way that makes you seem less important

examples.text: There’s no way he’ll go cap in hand to his brother.

definitions.definition: permission to marry somebody, especially a woman

examples.text: He asked the general for his daughter's hand in marriage.

definitions.definition: working closely with somebody, especially in a secret and/or illegal way
if two people are hand in hand, they are holding each other’s hand

examples.text: They walked through the park hand in hand.

definitions.definition: if two things go hand in hand, they are closely connected and one thing causes the other

examples.text: Poverty and poor health often go hand in hand.

definitions.definition: easily and without any doubt

examples.text: They **won hands down**.
It is hands down the best movie this year.

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody not to touch something/somebody

examples.text: Get your hands off my boyfriend!
Hey, hands off! That's my drink!
She warned her brother to keep his hands off her bag.

definitions.definition: used to tell a group of people to raise one hand in the air if they know the answer to a question, etc.

examples.text: Hands up all those who want to go swimming.

definitions.definition: used by somebody who is threatening people with a gun to tell them to raise both hands in the air
to be responsible for somebody’s death

examples.text: a dictator with the blood of thousands on his hands

definitions.definition: to be very busy or too busy to do something else

examples.text: They certainly have their hands full with four kids in the house.

definitions.definition: to be unable to do what you want to do because of rules, promises, etc.

examples.text: I really wish I could help but my hands are tied.

definitions.definition: to have complete control or influence over somebody

examples.text: Even before he plays a note, he has the audience in the palm of his hand.

definitions.definition: to have nothing to do or not be busy
to be in a position where you have power or control over somebody/something

examples.text: She had the whip hand and it was useless to resist.

definitions.definition: a way of doing something or of treating people that is much stronger and less sensitive than it needs to be

examples.text: the heavy hand of management

definitions.definition: to give somebody support in a difficult situation

examples.text: Do you want me to come along and hold your hand?

definitions.definition: to admit that you have made a mistake or are responsible for something bad

examples.text: I have to hold my hands up and admit that some of the problems have been all my own fault.
The solicitor confirmed that his clients were holding their hands up to the offences.

definitions.definition: being taken care of or dealt with by somebody that you think you can rely on

examples.text: Can I leave these queries in your capable hands?
He retired feeling confident that his company was in safe hands.

definitions.definition: if you have time or money in hand, it is left and available to be used

examples.text: We managed to redecorate the house and still have some savings in hand.
She completed the first part of the exam with over an hour in hand.

definitions.definition: if you have a particular situation in hand, you are in control of it

examples.text: Don’t worry about the travel arrangements—everything is in hand.

definitions.definition: the job, question, etc. in hand is the one that you are dealing with

examples.text: Please confine your comments to the topic in hand.

definitions.definition: if somebody works a week, month, etc. in hand, they are paid for the work a week, etc. after they have completed it
being taken care of or controlled by somebody

examples.text: The matter is now in the hands of my lawyer.
At that time, the castle was in enemy hands.

definitions.definition: being taken care of well by somebody

examples.text: I've left the kids in safe hands—with my parents.
Their problem was in the safe hands of the experts.

definitions.definition: if you use the words an iron fist/hand when describing the way that somebody behaves, you mean that they treat people severely. This treatment may be hidden behind a kind appearance (the velvet glove).

examples.text: They promised that the army would strike with an iron fist at any resistance.
The iron hand in the velvet glove approach seems to work best with this age group.

definitions.definition: used to say that you are too busy to do anything else
if two people join hands, they hold each other’s hands
to work together in doing something

examples.text: Education has been reluctant to join hands with business.

definitions.definition: to occasionally do something that you used to do a lot so that you do not lose your skill at it

examples.text: She retired last year but still teaches the odd class to keep her hand in.

definitions.definition: to be very familiar with somebody/something

examples.text: This is where I grew up. I know this area like the back of my hand.

definitions.definition: to catch somebody that you are annoyed with

examples.text: Wait till I get my hands on him!

definitions.definition: to find or get something

examples.text: I know their address is here somewhere, but I can't lay my hands on it right now.
I desperately need to get my hands on some money by Monday.

definitions.definition: to spend all the money you earn on basic needs such as food without being able to save any money
to make/lose money very fast and in large quantities
used to say that a job is made easier if a lot of people help
to do no work

examples.text: She hasn't done a hand's turn all week.

definitions.definition: to do nothing to help somebody

examples.text: The children never lift a finger to help around the house.

definitions.definition: to hold out your hand for somebody to shake
no longer your responsibility
on both/all sides; in both/all directions

examples.text: Mist curled from the water on either hand.

definitions.definition: available, especially to help

examples.text: The emergency services were on hand with medical advice.

definitions.definition: if you have somebody/something on your hands, you are responsible for or have to deal with them/it

examples.text: Let me take care of the invitations—you've enough on your hands with the caterers.
They’ll have a fight on their hands if they want to close down the school.

definitions.definition: used to introduce different points of view, ideas, etc., especially when they are opposites

examples.text: On the one hand they'd love to have kids, but on the other, they don't want to give up their freedom.

definitions.definition: difficult or impossible to control

examples.text: Unemployment is getting out of hand.

definitions.definition: if you reject, etc. something out of hand, you do so immediately without thinking about it fully or listening to other people’s arguments

examples.text: All our suggestions were dismissed out of hand.

definitions.definition: no longer your responsibility

examples.text: I'm afraid the matter is now out of my hands.

definitions.definition: to fail to achieve success by judging your position to be stronger than it really is
a person who can do, or is doing, a job

examples.text: We need an extra pair of hands if we're going to finish on time.

definitions.definition: to do exactly what an enemy, opponent, etc. wants so that they gain the advantage in a particular situation

examples.text: If we get the police involved, we'll be playing right into the protesters' hands.

definitions.definition: to spend money or give it to somebody

examples.text: I've heard he doesn't like putting his hand in his pocket.

definitions.definition: easily controlled or influenced by another person

examples.text: She'll persuade him. He's like putty in her hands.

definitions.definition: to hit or threaten to hit somebody
a person that you can trust to do a job well

examples.text: Colleagues regard him as a safe pair of hands.

definitions.definition: by being told about something by somebody else who has seen it or heard about it, not by experiencing, seeing, etc. it yourself

examples.text: I'm fed up of hearing about these decisions third hand!

definitions.definition: to make your plans or intentions known
a way of voting for or against something in which people raise their hands to vote

examples.text: The vote was passed by a show of hands.
Let’s have a show of hands. Who’s in favour of the proposal?

definitions.definition: to stop yourself from doing something; to prevent you from doing something

examples.text: It was prudence, not logic, that stayed his hand.

definitions.definition: to make yourself do something that you are afraid of

examples.text: Taking her courage in both hands, she opened the door and walked in.

definitions.definition: to deal with somebody in a strict way in order to improve their behaviour
to deal with a particular situation yourself because you are not happy with the way that others are dealing with it
to do something illegal in order to punish somebody for doing something wrong, instead of letting the police deal with them

examples.text: After a series of burglaries in the area, the police are worried that residents might take the law into their own hands.
When police failed to arrest the suspect, local people took the law into their own hands and beat him up.

definitions.definition: to risk being killed

examples.text: You take your life in your hands just crossing the road here.

definitions.definition: to stop doing something or taking part in something, especially because you are not successful
to raise both hands in the air to show that you are feeling annoyed or upset about something

examples.text: We threw up our hands in despair at the scale of the problem.

definitions.definition: that you can reach or get easily

examples.text: I'm afraid I don't have the latest figures to hand.
Keep a pen and paper to hand for details of this week’s competition.

definitions.definition: to do something such as an activity or a sport for the first time
to start doing something or be able to do something, especially when you do it well

examples.text: Jim can turn his hand to most jobs around the house.

definitions.definition: to take care of somebody’s needs so well that they do not have to do anything for themselves

examples.text: He seems to expect me to wait on him hand and foot.

definitions.definition: to refuse to be responsible for or involved with somebody/something

examples.text: When her son was arrested again she washed her hands of him.
I’ve washed my hands of the whole sordid business.

definitions.definition: to win something very easily
to press somebody’s hand very hard when you shake hands
to hold your hands together, and twist and press them together in a way that shows you are anxious or upset, especially when you cannot change the situation

wordOrigin: Old English hand, hond, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch hand and German Hand.
